header.title: Urban Voodoo: A Beginner's Guide to Afro-Caribbean Magic
header.category: Esotericism, Occultism, Afro-Caribbean Magic, Practical Magic, Self-Initiation

central_thesis: The book presents Afro-Caribbean magic (Voodoo, Santeria, Macumba) as a potent, practical, and results-oriented system for self-empowerment and direct interaction with spirits, contrasting it sharply with what the authors perceive as 'whitewashed,' 'psychologized,' or passive Western occultism and Christian traditions. It advocates for direct magical practice and self-initiation for 'outsiders' seeking tangible results and a form of 'guerrilla spiritual warfare' against oppressive religious philosophies.

structure_content.chapter_title: Other Titles From New Falcon Publications
structure_content.summary: Lists other esoteric and occult works published by New Falcon Publications, including previous collaborations by the authors, setting the contextual stage for the publisher's focus.
Presents the book's title, authors (S. Jason Black and Christopher S. Hyatt, Ph.D.), and publication year (1995) by New Falcon Publications, indicating its subject matter as Afro-Caribbean magic.

Provides copyright information (1995 B.M.I.T. for text, 1995 Richard Wardell for photographs), ISBN (1-56184-059-9), and Library of Congress Catalog Card Number (94-68556). It includes acknowledgments for cover art, drawings, photographs, and editing, alongside inquiry addresses for New Falcon Publications.

Expresses gratitude to Robert Williams for photographs, Steven Lang and Nancy Wasserman for editing, and particularly to 'Cici,' a Brazilian Macumba initiate, for providing otherwise unavailable information in English, highlighting the rare and authentic nature of some content.

Features various images depicting items typically found in a Botanica, such as candles, figures representing Death, oils, perfumes, amulets, talismans, Catholic saints used as masks for Orishas, dried herbs, and altar figures. These visuals illustrate the syncretic and practical aspects of Afro-Caribbean magic and its accessible tools.

Outlines the book's fifteen chapters, covering topics such as the purpose of the book, personal initiatory experiences, White Zombie, various Voodoo gods, divination techniques, spells, and self-initiation, providing a structural overview of the content.

structure_content.chapter_title: PREFACE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS BOOK
structure_content.summary: Explains the book's intention as a practical handbook for 'outsiders' interested in Voodoo, differentiating it from academic studies. It emphasizes the authors' personal 'eerie experiences' and aims to provide a guide for 'getting things done' through Afro-Caribbean magic, which they suggest might be 'the religion of the future'.

S. Jason Black recounts his unexpected discovery of a Botanica in Los Angeles and the widespread but overlooked presence of Voodoo/Brujeria supply shops. He criticizes the misidentification of Santeria practices as 'Satanic rituals' by police and media, highlighting ignorance and bigotry towards non-Christian religions.

S. Jason Black describes his personal 'conversion' to Afro-Caribbean magic, detailing early psychic experiences, including a powerful sympathetic magic incident where an abusive co-worker suffered unexplained stomach pains after Black visualized harming her. He also recounts a love charm's bizarre side effect and a protective spell's success, challenging Western occultism's 'psychologizing' of spirits by validating literal spirit interaction.

S. Jason Black expresses disillusionment with Western occult groups for their lack of genuine magical practice. He recounts a pendulum divination session that directed him to 'Ifa,' a Yoruba deity, leading to strange synchronicities, lucid dreams, and dramatic poltergeist phenomena (streetlights turning off on command), confirming direct spirit communication beyond his prior knowledge.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER THREE: THE GODS ARE ANGRY EFFENDI
structure_content.summary: S. Jason Black seeks advice from an occult store owner after experiencing poltergeist phenomena, learning he might be having 'spontaneous contacts with the Orishas.' He recounts the spirit's specific demands for altar items and an African head, refusing tarot but insisting on an African divination system. This leads him to attempt formal Santeria initiation, which a Santera advises against for a 'white boy'.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER FOUR: TELL MY HORSE—GO BACK TO MISSOURI
structure_content.summary: S. Jason Black recounts a period of job loss and financial hardship, during which a dream of a black coffin accurately predicted his termination. Later, a white dove with a broken neck, impaled on a Devil trump tarot card on his altar, served as a 'holy offering' signaling his departure. A subsequent I Ching divination predicted a car accident and legal trouble, which also came true, reinforcing the oracular accuracy despite personal cost.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER FIVE: DEAD MEN WORK IN THE FIELDS OF HOLLYWOOD
structure_content.summary: S. Jason Black resumes Afro-Caribbean magic experiments, emphasizing self-hypnosis for trance induction. He describes being compelled to buy William Gibson's *Count Zero*, which eerily depicted Voodoo daemons in cyberspace and a pun on his name relating to Legba. He then finds a physical 'sign' (Ebbo) on the street confirming Legba's presence, leading him to successfully perform a spell to transform his abusive employer's behavior, reinforcing the direct, tangible efficacy of Voodoo magic.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER SIX: SPIRITS THAT FINDETH HIDDEN TREASURE
structure_content.summary: The authors critique Western occultism's lack of practical results, contrasting it with Voodoo's efficacy. Jason Black recounts a spell for money that led to a gruesome animal sacrifice (rat in boiling water) as dictated by the spirit, resulting in his notoriously tight-fisted aunt unexpectedly giving him $2000 exactly when predicted. He also details a protection spell against crack dealers that led to their eviction and imprisonment after he invoked Baron Samedi.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER SEVEN: VOODOO IN THE WAITING ROOM
structure_content.summary: Christopher S. Hyatt, Ph.D., reflects on his attraction to Voodoo through 'Voodoo Death,' seeing it as a practical, joyous religion contrasting with Christianity's enslavement. He describes a 'middle-class nightmare' of witnessing a Haitian woman perform a chicken sacrifice for a love spell in a Los Angeles apartment, highlighting the raw, visceral reality of Voodoo versus his own 'chicken' middle-class anxieties.

Christopher S. Hyatt, Ph.D., contrasts Voodoo and Dionysian cults with Christianity, arguing the former offer 'power, frenzy, and joy' through active participation and direct spirit interaction, embracing lust and the interconnectedness of life/death. He critiques Christianity as passive, repressive, and generating fear-based morality, asserting that Voodoo embodies a more 'organic and lusty' approach to The Numinous, akin to ancient Greek traditions.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER NINE: SPIRITS, MAGICAL THEORY & PSYCHIC REPRESSION
structure_content.summary: The authors define magic by its interaction with spirits, mind, and matter, criticizing Western occult groups for 'psychologizing' spirits and fearing supernatural phenomena. They assert the literal existence of spirits and Voodoo's focus on 'direct experience and results,' contrasting it with intellectualizing magic. They also describe how spirits are treated like 'business associates' and require offerings, including blood sacrifices, and the importance of trance states for communication.

This chapter introduces five Afro-Caribbean divination methods: Tarot Cards, the Pendulum (a balanced weight for spirit communication), the Obi (four cola nuts/objects tossed for Odu patterns), Caracoles (cowry shells, simplified for beginners), and Possession (Altered States of Consciousness). It provides detailed instructions on how to construct and use the Oracle, interpret the Odu, and outlines techniques for trance induction and self-hypnosis as crucial for direct spirit interaction.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER ELEVEN: THE LORDS OF THE CROSSROADS
structure_content.summary: This chapter details the crucial trickster spirit 'Eshu' (also Eleggua, Legba, Kalfu, Baron Carrefour), who is solar-phallic, master of crossroads, and essential for all rituals. It lists 21 Eshus with their attributes and sigils from Santeria/Lucumi and Brazilian Macumba. It explains how to consecrate an Eshu head (bust or coconut) as a spirit home, with offerings like candy, rum, cigars, and blood sacrifice, emphasizing their mercurial nature and the need for appeasement.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER TWELVE: SOME OTHER MEMBERS OF THE FAMILY
structure_content.summary: This chapter introduces other important Orishas beyond Eshus, including the Ibeyi twins (Taebo and Kainde), Chango, Oshun, Ogun, Ochosi, and Yemanja. For each, it provides their attributes, associated Catholic 'masks,' colors, sacred places, preferred offerings (including blood sacrifices for some), and invocations, detailing their roles in magic (e.g., healing, love, luck, war, hunting, fertility) and their unique personalities.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER THIRTEEN: COCAINE, ZOMBIES & CAULDRONS OF BLOOD: THE DARK SIDE
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores the darker, often sensationalized aspects of Afro-Caribbean magic, citing instances like General Noriega's Voodoo altar and accounts of 'zombie' individuals in Brazil, and Idi Amin's use of black magicians. It introduces Palo Mayombe, a necromantic tradition involving human remains in cauldrons ('nganga') to bind spirits, and recounts the atrocities committed by a powerful Palero, Adolfo Luis Constanzo, highlighting the effective but dangerous nature of 'black magic'.

This chapter provides outlines for practical Voodoo spells, emphasizing their functional nature and the practitioner as an 'ultimate pragmatist' willing to use any effective material, including European Grimoires. It details rituals for attraction, dissension, blocking enemies, removing/destroying enemies (including doll magic and 'funerals'), prosperity, and cleansing, stressing the importance of 'magical links,' specific spirit invocations, offerings (including blood), and ritual cleansing of space.

This chapter addresses the question of initiation in Voodoo and other esoteric traditions, questioning the necessity and authenticity of formal initiations in groups like the Golden Dawn. It advocates for self-initiation for 'outsiders' or those 'called' to magic, citing Israel Regardie's view that persistent solitary practice can be as effective. It provides a specific self-initiation method involving ritual baths, an altar to Legba/Eshu, self-hypnosis for trance, and dream journaling, warning of potentially frightening but rewarding experiences.

key_concepts.definition: A modern, practical, and accessible adaptation of Afro-Caribbean magic for outsiders and lone practitioners, emphasizing direct spirit communication and tangible results, often framed as 'guerrilla spiritual warfare' against conventional religious philosophies.

A collective term encompassing New World religious and magical systems (Vaudun, Santeria, Macumba, Palo Mayombe) derived from African traditions, characterized by syncretism, direct spirit interaction, and focus on practical outcomes.

Discarnate entities with distinct personalities, powers, and needs, treated as conscious 'organisms' or 'business associates' by practitioners, invoked and offered to for specific magical purposes, rejecting psychological interpretations.

Magic is presented as a pragmatic technology for interacting with and influencing the phenomenal world for desired results, but also as an art requiring 'inborn talent' or 'mediumship' for effective practice.

The process of engaging in magical practice without formal initiation into a group or tradition, advocated for 'outsiders' and 'rogues' who are 'called' by spirits, emphasizing persistence, direct experience, and personal responsibility over credentials or traditional hierarchical structures.
A physical object, typically effluvia (e.g., a used condom), an article of clothing, a signature, or a picture, used to establish a psychic connection with a target person or a spirit for a spell.

Material gifts (e.g., rum, cigars, candy, yams, fruits, specific animals like pigeons, rats, lobster, spinal cord blood) given to spirits as a direct 'payment' or 'exchange' for their assistance, often in Voodoo style, not as passive worship.

Techniques for communicating with spirits and gaining information, including the Pendulum, Obi, Caracoles (Cowry Shells), Tarot Cards, I Ching, and spontaneous 'possession' or trance states, considered integral to effective magical practice.

The authors' critical term for the tendency in Western occultism and psychotherapy to explain away genuine spirit phenomena as mere psychological constructs (e.g., 'Jungian archetypes,' 'the unconscious'), which they view as a form of 'psychic repression' and denial of literal spirit existence.

The most important class of trickster spirits in Voodoo pantheons, masters of crossroads, communication, and all magic. They are solar-phallic, unpredictable, and must be invoked and offered to at the beginning of any ceremony to ensure success and prevent mischief.
The five distinct patterns formed by tossing the Obi (divination objects), each with specific divinatory meanings, which can be further combined into 'Omo Odu' for more detailed interpretations.

A necromantic Afro-Caribbean tradition with Congo roots, involving the use of human remains (e.g., skull, bones) placed in an 'nganga' or 'prenda' (iron cauldron) to house and bind spirits of the dead for magical purposes.

A key preparatory technique for magical practice, involving focused concentration on a crystalline object, repetitive affirmations, and controlled breathing to achieve a hypnogogic state for direct communication with spirits and enhanced psychic functioning.

practical_system.description: The book outlines a pragmatic, results-oriented system of Afro-Caribbean magic, emphasizing direct communication with spirits and tangible manifestation in the physical world. It integrates elements from Haitian Vaudun, Brazilian Macumba, and Cuban Santeria/Lucumi, alongside concepts from Western ceremonial magic, portraying the practitioner as an 'ultimate pragmatist.' The core methodology involves establishing 'magical links' with targets, invoking specific spirits (Eshus/Orishas) with appropriate offerings, and utilizing various divination methods for guidance. A key preparatory technique is self-hypnosis to achieve trance states for enhanced spirit communication.
tools: Obi (cola nuts, coconut pieces, flattened glass beads, or coins)
Candles (various colors, effigy candles, Santeria candles)
Cayenne Pepper, Asafoetida, Stinging Nettles, Wasp/Scorpion (for destructive spells)
Live Fowl (pigeons, roosters, turkey, quail) / Rats / Live Fish / Crustaceans (for sacrifice)
rituals: Spirit Invocation/Conjuration: Direct calls to specific spirits (e.g., Legba, Eshus, Oshun, Chango, Baron Samedi) for assistance, protection, or harm, requiring clear verbal requests and specific offerings.

Offerings/Sacrifice: Material gifts (e.g., rum, cigars, candy, yams, fruits, specific animal blood from pigeons, rats, lobster, spinal cord) provided to spirits as a direct exchange for their services, presented as a necessary and traditional aspect of magic.

Cleansing Rituals: Methods to purify oneself and the ritual space, such as splashing 'Florida water' or other colognes/incense, or performing ritual baths with specific invocations (e.g., 'LORD GOD ADONAY').

Protective Charms/Spells: Creation and use of talismans (e.g., clay objects, inscribed items, mojo bags) and consecrated objects, combined with invocations to spirits for defense, good luck, or to deflect harm.

Attraction Spells: Utilizing 'magical links' of the desired person (effluvia, clothing, picture, name on paper), placed with lodestones/magnets, honey/syrup, and invoking spirits like Oshun or the Ibeyi twins with offerings.
Dissension Spells: Similar to attraction spells but using 'links' for two people placed in vinegar to cause conflict or a falling out.
Blocking Spells: Carving a target's name on a black effigy candle, invoking Eshu Da Capa Preta to cause failure, and then either magically imprisoning the wax or burying it with rum.

Enemy Removal/Destruction Spells: Crafting Voodoo dolls (cloth, wax, clay) with 'magical links,' filled with harmful substances (e.g., cayenne pepper, stinging nettles, scorpion), invoked with destructive spirits (e.g., Eshu Da Capa Preta, Baron Samedi), then bound, buried, or subjected to an impromptu 'funeral' in a miniature coffin.

Money/Prosperity Spells: Invoking Oshun (with green candles, money-drawing oil, silver/gold offerings) or other appropriate spirits, anointing offerings with blood of sacrifice, and carrying charged talismans.
Enemy Departure Spells: Using 'graveyard earth' charged via invocation, scattered on the target's path, to compel their removal from one's vicinity.

Self-Initiation Ritual: A solitary practice involving a ritual bath, setting up a devotional altar with a crossroad spirit (Eleggua) figure/sigil, using a crystalline object for self-hypnosis to achieve trance, direct spirit communication, and maintaining a dream diary.

relevant_quotes.text: Urban Voodoo is indeed about the practice of magic and spells, but more importantly it is written for the person born outside the Voodoo tradition—which is still often closed to outsiders—but interested in the practice. It is also focused on the frequently eerie experiences of the authors, who, like the reader, came in contact with Voodoo from outside.

We decided to write this book for two reasons: first to describe the remarkable experiences and benefits we both gained from this most ancient and “pure” strain of magic, and also to encourage involvement by “outsiders” in what may prove to be the religion of the future.
The emphasis of this book is on magic, and not religion or any system o f social control or moralizing.

Where the Judeo-Christian religions and most of the New Age movement tell you to repress your emotions and desires and to (pretend to) think “happy thoughts”, we say, along with the ancient Voodoo gods, that desire is honorable, that anger may well be justified, that the will to power is nothing to be ashamed of.
Many of the books I have read on Voodoo have, in a w ell meaning, but pompous fashion, insisted that these practices should not be undertaken without initiation. We flatly deny this.
The magic works, and blends as nicely now, in the infor mation age, as it did in the time of the schooner. Maybe better.
By magic I definitely do not mean “Gnostic Masses” or “Drawing Down The Moon” or any other “religious” ritual that calls itself magic.

This is one of the finest examples of “primitive” sympathetic magic that I have ever experienced. Except for the location in Los Angeles, and the fact that the doll was in my mind and not physical reality, this story could have come from one of those “Ju-Ju in my life” books British explorers used to write.

I asked myself that if I was communicating with a part of my unconscious as some occultists theorize (or dogmatically state) why did “it” not use these? Why speak to me through an African system I had no knowledge o f “It” refused to have anything to do with this material for almost six months— as though it needed to learn.
The great virtue of Voodoo in contrast to other paths is direct experience and the pursuit of results.

In Voodoo (indeed in all traditional magic) spirits are dealt with as you would any friend or business associate of flesh and blood. They are spoken to clearly, greeted in a way that betokens respect, and paid for the requested service. This is an important point that cannot be glossed over.

Magic is a technology o f interacting with, and influencing the phenomenal world on a desired level, physical or otherwise. Spirits are organisms, too, and even if they don’t appear to eat something, they certainly want something.

Voodoo is about function and not artificial divisions based on meaningless sectarian symbolism. This, from our experience, seems to be one of the hardest things for people raised in a white Christian world to get past.

No Bocor or Palero would hesitate to use material from the Key of Solomon or any other European Grimoire if he thought it would work, and we urge you to take the same attitude. In this sense the Voodoo practitioner is the ultimate pragmatist.
Patience and commitment are the keys to making this work.

critical_analysis.relevance: The book offers a radical, results-oriented alternative to conventional Western occultism and religious thought, emphasizing the direct, tangible efficacy and cultural resilience of Afro-Caribbean magical traditions. Its critique of 'psychologizing' magic and 'Christian bigotry' remains highly relevant in contemporary discussions about religious syncretism, cultural authenticity, and the 'demonic panic' often surrounding non-Western spiritual practices. It directly addresses the disconnect between theoretical esoteric study and actual operative magic, positioning itself as a guide for practical application.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of 'outsiders' to established Voodoo traditions, 'lone practitioners,' and 'serious students' of magic disillusioned with ineffective or overly intellectualized Western occult groups. It appeals to individuals seeking tangible results, self-empowerment, and a willingness to engage in potentially 'frightening' psychic experiences. It explicitly rejects those seeking 'spiritual advancement' as conventionally defined, instead targeting pragmatists interested in direct, personal engagement with spirit entities for real-world outcomes.
